newsitem.title: USA: Time Warner says to unveil online service.
newsitem.headline: Time Warner says to unveil online service.

text.p: Time Warner Inc planned to introduce on Tuesday a high-speed online service called Road Runner that will operate over a cable network and through a cable modem, the company said in a statement.

"Road Runner (will begin) delivering a wide range of exclusive content to Akron and Canton (Ohio) area customers via their personal computers at unparalleled speeds," Time Warner said. "We expect Road Runner to become a significant new business for Time Warner Cable."
It will carry "compelling" proprietary national and local content and will be launched elsewhere soon, Time Warner said.

Road Runner will connect users to the Internet, e-mail and other online services via Time Warner Cable's upgraded 3,000-mile fiber optic/coaxial cable network here, it said. Traditional modems use local telephone lines.

Hewlett-Packard Co built Road Runner's computer servers and routers, Time Warner said, and Motorola Inc built the cable modems that connect the fiber optic/coaxial network with customers' personal computers.

MCI Communications Corp is providing Internet connectivity and customer care, and customers will navigate the service using a customized version of Microsoft Corp's Explorer 3.0 Internet browser, Time Warner said.

Time Warner Cable said its chairman and chief executive officer, Joseph Collins, planned to unveil the service on Tuesday at Inventure Place, a hands-on science learning center and museum that houses the National Inventors Hall of Fame.

"Road Runner ... represents a creative combination of the sophisticated technological part of Time Warner Cable and the vast journalistic resources of Time Inc with the unrivaled entertainment talent of Warner Bros," he said in the statement. Time and Warner are Time Warner units, and the service is named after a Warner Bros. cartoon bird.
The Akron Beacon Journal and the Canton Repository newspapers and Time Inc's Time, People, Money and Sports Illustrated magazines will provide electronic news.
Independent content suppliers will offer a Medical Advisor Online, Home Improvement Encyclopedia and other features.

Local net sites will feature libraries and public schools, art museums, Akron and Canton city halls, Inventure Place and sports entities such as a minor-league baseball team here and the Pro Football Hall of Fame, which is in Canton.
"I am really excited about what this service will mean for our school children," Stephen Fry, president of Time Warner Cable in Northeast Ohio, said in the statement.
Time Warner Cable, the second largest U.S. cable television operator with 1.8 million customers, said it plans to supply the service and modems free to local schools.
Time Warner said it had more than 400 customers online before the service was formally launched and had more than 1,000 on a waiting list.
